Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: I sat at my desk, the blue glow of my monitor reflecting off the mug of untouched tea beside me. My code editor was open, lines of logic blurring together as I scrolled through the latest review comments. “Performance bottleneck here,” one note read. My team was counting on me to fix it before tomorrow’s release. I knew I needed to focus, to write code that was not just functional but elegant and efficient. But my phone buzzed again—another message from my husband. He was struggling, lost in a storm of grief after his father’s diagnosis, and I was his anchor. He needed me to listen, to reassure him, to be present. I could hear his voice in my mind, shaky and uncertain, asking if I could come sit with him. My heart twisted. I wanted to be the wife he needed, to hold him and promise it would be okay. But the code review window blinked at me, demanding my attention, my expertise. I stared at the screen, torn between the two worlds, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which to answer first.
